thread.title_full: A Portable Roman Snack on the Lower East Side - The New York Times

author: Florence Fabricant
title: A Portable Roman Snack on the Lower East Side - The New York Times
text: Continue reading the main story Photo Specialties at Trapizzino. A new location on the Lower East Side of Manhattan will open this week. Credit Morgan Ione Yeager for The New York Times A Trapizzino is a thick triangle of crusty bread split open and filled with classics like hearty meatballs, chicken cacciatore or even braised tongue in green sauce. This Roman-style snack is the work of Stefano Callegari, who has a number of such places in the Eternal City. The bread is the edible container, like a pita pocket. “It’s a way to get people to appreciate the traditional food of Rome,” Mr. Callegari said. At his new Lower East Side location, opening on Wednesday, you get a substantial amount of food for $6. Suppli, which are like oversize arancini but with a creamier filling, are another specialty: Trapizzino, 144 Orchard Street (Rivington Street), 212-475-2555, trapizzinousa.com .
